title: Jurgen Klopp: I heard Liverpool had seven Ballon d'Or nominees and my first question was, 'who is not nominated?'
text:
There is nothing more symbolic of Liverpool’s restored pedigree than being European champions, but Jurgen Klopp has acknowledged another sign of his club's return to elite status in the form of this year’s Ballon d’Or nominations.

Seven of Klopp’s side will fight for the most coveted individual honour in European football, Virgil van Dijk hoping to overcome serial winners Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo.

The scale of that recognition is extraordinary given no players outside Real Madrid and Barcelona have won the Ballon d’Or since 2008. With the exception of Pavel Nedved in 2003 and Andriy Shevchenko in 2004 - every winner since 1998 either played for or subsequently signed for the two La Liga superpowers.

Van Dijk could be the first centre-back winner since Fabio Cannavaro, who won while a Real Madrid player in 2006. When Liverpool last won the Champions League in 2005, only three players - Steven Gerrard, Jamie Carragher and Luis Garcia - made the shortlist.

Proof of a European power shift? Not quite, said Klopp. But he welcomed the recognition.
